awd_titl_txt: CIF:Medium:Convex Optimization for Blind Inverse Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the fundamental tasks in processing sensor and imaging data
is to solve an inverse problem, determining the nature of some
fundamental structure that produced that data. Such problems are
often underdetermined, meaning that the number of unknowns exceeds
the number of observations, and these problems are even more
complicated in the blind setting, where the fundamental structure
may undergo some unknown transformation en route to the sensor.
This project considers a number of such blind inverse problems,
including non-stationary deconvolution, where an unknown point
spread function changes over time; multi-band signal
identification, where line spectrum estimation is extended to
signals with multiple narrow frequency bands; super-resolution
radar imaging, where extended and accelerating targets may cause
unwanted spreading in the delay-Doppler space; and simultaneous
blind deconvolution and phase retrieval. Conventionally, all of
these problems have been studied separately. This project
investigates all of the problems jointly under a unifying
optimization and analysis framework.

By modeling unknown transformation operators using subspaces, the
investigators transform each non-convex inverse problem into a
linear inverse problem of recovering a structured signal. This
signal is a parsimonious mixture of lifted atoms generated by the
original atomic set, allowing the investigators to enforce its
simplicity using a new atomic norm. The investigators develop novel
analysis techniques to demonstrate the optimality of this framework
by deriving sampling complexities that achieve the
information-theoretical limits, calculating mean-squared denoising
errors that match the minimax rates, and developing parameter
estimation bounds that approach the Cramer-Rao bounds. The project
builds on the investigators' combined expertise in signal
processing, convex optimization in continuously parameterized
inverse problems, and geometric modeling.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated fundamental challenges in solving blind inverse problems, a class of signal processing problems where the signals of interest undergo unknown transformations before being observed. By leveraging convex optimization, atomic norm minimization, and subspace modeling, we developed theoretical frameworks and practical algorithms for solving complex inverse problems that can arise in applications such as radar imaging, structural health monitoring, communications, array processing, and medical imaging. For such problems, the overarching goals of the project were to develop novel algorithms to recover structured signals from limited, noisy, or incomplete data; establish optimal sampling complexities that meet information-theoretic limits; derive denoising error bounds that match minimax rates; calculate parameter estimation bounds approaching the Cramer-Rao lower bounds; and design deep neural networks for solving such problems with architectures inspired by a mathematical understanding of the optimization algorithms.


The intellectual contributions of this project were extensive. The project led to significant advances in super-resolution, demodulation, and spectral estimation. One accomplishment was the development of novel optimization methods for non-stationary blind super-resolution, where motivating applications range from radar imaging to 3D single-molecule microscopy. A notable contribution was the formulation of multi-band signal identification as a convex optimization problem using atomic norm minimization. This problem is an extension of classical line spectrum estimation to signals whose composite waveforms occupy continuous frequency bands rather than discrete spikes. Our approach allowed for precise estimation of spectral components. One application of this approach is in the localization of extended, non-point targets using stepped frequency radar. The project also introduced innovative solutions for radar signal demixing, addressing the challenge of separating contributions from targets, jammers, and clutter in airborne radar systems. Additionally, to deal with damped spectrally sparse signal recovery problems, we offered a novel optimization-based perspective on the classical MUSIC (MUltiple SIgnal Classification) algorithm and proposed an extension to the algorithm for the missing data case. Finally, we explored related problems in beamforming and multi-frequency direction of arrival estimation in array processing.


Relatedly, for super-resolution imaging, the project proposed a convex feasibility program to localize non-negative point sources in images (such as astronomical images) blurred by the point spread function of the imaging device. This approach achieved stable recovery even in the presence of noise or model mismatch, and theoretical analysis established the conditions under which this method guarantees exact recovery of the point sources. Additionally, the project addressed the problems of simultaneous blind deconvolution and phase retrieval, as well as simultaneous sparse recovery and blind demodulation.


Another significant theoretical contribution of this work was the development of new insights into the landscape of non-convex optimization problems. In certain matrix and tensor optimization problems, we analyzed why simple iterative algorithms, such as gradient descent, can perform well despite the presence of non-convexity, and we provided conditions under which optimization formulations lead to globally optimal solutions. This research contributed to a broader understanding of the mathematical structures underlying signal recovery problems, with additional implications in machine learning.


The broader impacts of this project extend to education, outreach, and societal benefits. The project trained graduate and undergraduate students in advanced signal processing and optimization techniques, leading to dissertations, journal articles, and conference presentations, and equipping the students with skills for careers in engineering, research, and industry. Concepts derived from the research were also integrated into graduate-level courses on convex optimization, sparse signal processing, and numerical optimization at the Colorado School of Mines and the University of Colorado-Boulder.


Outreach efforts included the development and delivery of STEM education materials for dyslexic students. Outreach lessons and activities, shared through platforms like the TeachEngineering digital library and delivered virtually to local students during the COVID pandemic, reached a wide audience. The project also facilitated a significant growth of our STEM outreach partnership with the Greater Colorado Council of the Boy Scouts of America.


Finally, the potential societal benefits of the scientific research in this project are widespread. From radar systems to wireless communications, from astronomical imaging to medical imaging, with applications of structural health monitoring in preserving aging infrastructure, and with the emergence of powerful artificial intelligence technologies, our project furthers understanding, efficiency, and accuracy which can lead to more powerful, higher resolution systems at lower cost in the future.
